sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Well I see Tom, thou hast not a Spirit, a Genius for Intrigue— there is often more Pleasure in the Design than the thing— now shou'd I never rest till I had made the Husband accessary, it sweetens the Stealth, and makes it more secure, or if no Husband a Brother that is Jealous of the Honour of his Family— why Tom, I have imploy'd Fathers and Mothers in this Business!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Nay Sir Solomon, there is none so fit to take care of 'em as they that get 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ha! ha! My witty Rogue— sure she's mightily pleas'd with you!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: She tells me so.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ye happy Dog!— but prithee Tom tell me a little more for I love to find my Plots Succeed, what sort of Wench is it— ha!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: A Beauty able to renew the long lost Fire in your Heart, and turn you to a Rival.

sp.speaker: Sir Sal.
sp.p: Egad sirrah, I'd Cuckold ye if I knew her, for this Libel— hah! Hem! I'am as Strong as you are— but no more of that, kneel down and thank me for my Advice— I understand the World Tom! But go on, is she Black or Fair, Tall or Short? Ha!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: She's neither, but agreeably divided between 'em all— her Mien is easie without Affectation, and in her Face a pretty Haughtiness appears that melts it self into a Smile, and every Heart that sees it into Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: But Dear Tom, how was she set off, what Rigging had she? Ha!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I was not so Idle as to make a Critick on her Dress, but I think she had a Yellow Gown—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Yellow Gown!— Pray Heaven it's not my Wife all this time. aside.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Ay Yellow! Why don't you like that Colour?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: O very well, very well Tom— Yellow you say? And what else?— it must be she. aside.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And Black upper Petty-coat—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Upper Petty-coat?— then he has too— aside.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir Solomon, you're Concern'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: No, no, no, not at all Tom— Black upper Petty-coat! aside. you meet her at six you say, Ha! Tom!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Solomon, there's the Challenge she sent me next my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: S'death! this is confirmation! The Gypsy's own Hand!
sp.stage: The Garden Door— open— and— exactly at six— your—— Expecting Caelia.
sp.p: Caelia! Ay that's her Contrivance— Cockatrice! aside.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: There must be something in this Disorder, Cleremont told me he was Married— I have gone too far—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: This is her Devotion! Well I'll know more, and if she has— Ha! Ha! Ha! Tom, this is very kind, you must not disappoint her for the World.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: No, Sir Solomon, I'm a Man of Honour— but the unluckyest Dog that ever was. aside.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My Friend and Councellour, Sir Solomon Empty! Ha! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay I have Counsell'd—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I follow'd your Instructions and am Happy— I melted the Doctor, and He my Mistress; all her Aversions to me are over, her Pukings, her Spleen, her Swoonings, her Cholick! And now I am as well-come and agreeable to her as a Dose of Physick— all this my Councellour and deep Politician in Love I owe to thy sage Advice— Thou doest indeed understand the World, and in all Love Intrigues I'll be rul'd by no other— but what's the matter, are you both Dumb?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol. Fre.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: No, no, I was only thinking of a Business of Freeman's—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Which I must mind Gentlemen, and so your Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: And I too— going.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Hold Sir Solomon you must stay and hear my success.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: I can't, I have Business.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A Pox, O' Business— Ha! Ha! Ha! You can't think what a change of Affairs it wrought.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Puh!—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I find the Plain Honest Way never does it, and a Man may throw away as much Money upon a Mistress as a Place at Court, and never be the nearer.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Upper Petty-coat!—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A little bribe well Plac'd— but Sir Solomon methinks you are not pleas'd enough with the success of your Counsels.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: If I an't, I'm in the wrong, for they have took mightily, mightily!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O beyond expectation!

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay with a Pox!—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: She receiv'd me with all the Ease and Satisfaction that desiring Lovers use, all her talk was with regard to me and all her Appeals were to me—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Your Expecting Caelia!—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Cou'd you a' Dreamt that it wou'd come to this?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: No Faith I cou'd not— not in the least Mr. Cleremont, not in the least!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why thou deservest a Statue to thy Memory.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: I do indeed deserve one—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou doest— why some have been worship'd for half thy Sagacity— you don't know your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do, I am wiser than ever, Mr. Cleremont, and know my self intimately!— rubbing his forehead.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: All the distress'd Lovers in Town will fly to you for Succour.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Very likely— The Garden door at Six? Aside.— I won't, I can't, I must not, dare not stay any longer.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a Devil's the Matter now? But thou art an Extraordinary old Fellow—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: So! My Disguise sits well he'll never know me— now let me consider— what strange Story must I tell him to get him out of the way— but I shan't want invention; I'll tickle his Ears as I us'd to do the Commisarys when we made up a false Muster.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Jezebel! Harlot! This is her Aversion to Men! Her Praying! Her Piety!— but this is my Advice too. I must be giving Counsel!— hum— Enter Careless.
But what Fellow's that? I don't like him— he may be a Cuckold-maker too for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Here he is, now for my Plot— Sir, Is your Name Sir Solomon Empty?

sp.speaker: Sir. Sol.
sp.p: Yes 'tis— what then?— Thou art a Rogue I believe. aside.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Do you know one Sir Humphrey Afterwit?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey Afterwit!— No not I— not I Fellow— I know none of your Sir Humpherys— (aside) some poor Dog or other in Prison— there's such new ways of begging since the War—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I don't know how 'tis Sir, but he said he was near related to the Family of the Emptys, and dyed at my House Yesterday.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Why then you must bury him Friend— don't trouble me with your dead Men— Upper Pettycoat. aside.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But a little before he dy'd, he bid me go to Sir Solomon Empty, and pay him a considerable Sum of Money that he ow'd him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Adds me!— Harkee Friend— Sir Humphery Afterwit!— what an unlucky Brain have I! Ha! ha! ha! My dear Friend— Afterwit! that ever I should be puzzled to remember Thee!— and I protest to you he was as perfectly out of my Head, as if he had never been there.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Very likely Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Why we are first Cousens— but he is not dead sure, he can't be dead!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Indeed Sir he is— he just came to Town, fell sick and dy'd in two Hours.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Tell me no more! The News goes to my Heart— poor Have— Wit!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, he said his Name was Afterwit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Right, right, Afterwit! But Grief, 'tis Grief makes me forget what I say— I have lost the best Friend!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I suppose you know how much it is?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: No Friend, I can think of nothing now— poor Numps Dead!— go in and pay it any of my Servants.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, he charg'd me to pay it none but you, and I was afraid to venture so much about me, but if you'll do me the Honour to go to my House.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Well, come lets go then, I shall be out of Pain the sooner— Ho! my dear Friend gone— poor Lackwit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Your too great Care has ruin'd us!— had you not conceal'd your Name—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Who cou'd ha' thought that Sir Solomon had been your intimate Acquaintance— I never heard him speak of such a Man— but I'm undone, past Redemption lost.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Sure there's a way.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: O! none, never think on't— had you not shown the Letter—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: That unfortunate Letter!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p:
Cursed Letter!— if you had delay'd your Discovery two Hours, I had prevented it by telling you all— I had begun with your Man,
and sent him to draw Sir Solomon out of the way, which now I suppose he can't compass— and if you had seen him first.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How unlucky it was!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: But we must do something— let me consider— He'll certainly be there— hum— O I have it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How, how dear Creature!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: O! Sir you'll tell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You are unkind, but I deserve it— yet pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I have thought of a Device that must bring us off, let me see the Letter.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Here! here!

sp.speaker: Fre:
sp.p: I never knew a Woman plung'd at an Excuse; now were I to be hang'd, I cou'd not think of an Expedient, I see so many Dangers— but Woman!—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: 'Tis well— leave me— (gives him back the Letter.)

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Must I not know your Plot?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Ask me nothing, but come at the Hour, and behave your self as you wou'd ha' done, had this not happen'd; leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I go.—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I'm glad you're here; run immediately and call my Cousen—

I have a thousand Fears— I wish it were over— let me see— she loves him too! it distracts me— was ever Woman so reduc'd!— but there's no other way. I must lose my Lover or my— Honour! Quiet! every thing! the fame of so much Vertue and be expos'd— I can't think on't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I ply'd him every Minute with fresh Storys, and told more lyes than are pardon'd at a Jubilee.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I am glad they did not, but how came they not to succeed?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I can't tell what was in his Head, but I had not got half way when he turn'd short, and bid me be at home to morrow, for he had extraordinary Business.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Damn his Business.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And him too. Sir for a Dog— a French Husband wou'd a been better bred than to look into the Affairs of his Wife— but we have nothing in that Perfection as abroad, and our Cuckolds as well as our Grapes are but half ripen'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, the things that are most cultivated, our very Fops in England are not to be nam'd with theirs— a true bred English Beau has indeed the Powder, the Essence, the Tooth-pick, the Snuff-box, and is as
Idle, but the fault is in the Flesh, he has not the motion, and looks stiff under all this— Now a French Fop, like a Poet, is born so, and wou'd be known without Cloaths, it is in his Eyes, his Nose, his Fingers, his Elbows, his Heels; they Dance when they Walk, and sing when they speak—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You're extreamly Diverting.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I wou'd fain drive this ugly Business out of your Head, for it puts you as much out of humour as a Dun in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And as much at a loss, as when I have no Money for him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Never fear Sir, if she has undertook to bring you off.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why are you acquainted with her Skill in these Matters?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No Sir, but I never knew a Design fail where a Woman was the Ingineer— the Plots that don't succeed are made by Men.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Ay, but there is more in that it Thou art aware of— how if it shake my Interest with the Fortune?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, for when once a Woman loves, nothing Cures her but Glutting.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Yet a modest Woman will be startl'd at such Galantries.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In appearance she may, but a wild Man has always their secret approbation, and every Woman has the Vanity to think she can keep him to her self.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Do'ye think so?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And hope you'll find so— I never doubt a thing that depends on a Woman's Opinion of her self, for Nature has so order'd it that every one is prepar'd to believe whatever we can say of 'em.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Did you find her Maid of that Humour?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She wou'd not listen to me because she did not like me (I pity her Judgment) but I never knew a Woman refuse a Man that she lik'd— when they don't Fancy, they are very Saucy and very Vertuous.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Prithee Careless, leave this Libel and Mind the present Business— 'tis pretty near the Time, go to the Mall and wait for orders— you'll find me in this Walk.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yonder's one that will divert you in the mean time, the Charming Mrs. Friendlove.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Her Impertinence was never so unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Faith Sir, according to the present Posture of Affairs, I fancy she might be very seasonable.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why thus;— You are not sure they will succeed in their Plot upon Sir Solomon, now it will at least perplex the Matter if you can draw her thither about that time, to consummate the Wedding that you have put in her Head.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: But if they should succeed it might raise new Jealousies in him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To prevent that I may be ready to lead her another way.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I like it, let's meet her.

div.stage: Enter Lady Dainty, Clarinda and Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Well, I must confess Mr. Cleremont you are the most Diverting Man in the World, and the best Company when one has taken the Waters, and I have drank Epsome this Morning.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: His Discourse Madam; seems more peculiar to a Steel Mineral; for Reproach and Scandal, at which he is very happy, eases us of Spleen and Dissatisfaction with our selves, and might be very proper to assist the operations of Tunbridge.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You are extreamly in the Right, and that must be the reason that makes Tunbridge so Fruitful of Lampoons, for that Mineral not being strong enough to make the crudities of Ill-nature pass, they are forc'd to bring 'em up in Verse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Upon which Account Madam, all the Nice Women in the Town go thither to divert their Spleen, and be abus'd, for Detraction is always so entertaining to the Ladies, that rather than want it they will have it at their own Expence.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Well, you are certainly a Living Lampoon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Since then Madam, you acknowledge me so Medicinal to you, throw away your Juleps, Cordials, Slops, and take me all at once.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: No Mr. Cleremont, that's too Bitter a Potion to be taken so suddainly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh! The rather Madam, the rather; for if you stand making Faces at what goes against you, it does but increase your Aversion and delay the Cure— Come, you must be Advis'd. presses her.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: To banish all your Ails and be my self your universal Medicine.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Impudent robust Man!— I protest did not I know his Relations, I-shou'd think his Parents had not liv'd in Chairs and Coaches, but had us'd their Limbs all their Lives— Huh! Huh! But I begin to be perswaded Health is a great Blessing— aside.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My Limbs Madam, were convey'd to me from before the use of Chairs and Coaches, and it might lessen the Dignity of my Ancestors not to use 'em as they did.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Was ever such a rude Understanding? To value himself upon the Barbarism of his Fore-fathers? Indeed I have heard of Kings that were bred to the Plough and fancy you might Descend from such a Race, for you Court as if you were behind one— Huh! Huh! Huh!— to treat a Woman of Quality like an Exchange Wench, and express your Passion with your Arms, unpolish'd Man!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I was willing Madam, to take from the Vulgar the only desireable thing amongst 'em, and show you how they live so Healthy— for they have no other Remedy.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: A very rough Medicine! Huh! Huh!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: To those that never took it, it may seem so— pressing her.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Abandon'd Ravisher! Leave the room, and see my Face no more—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: And harkee Sir 〈◊〉 Bribes, no Mediations to my Woman.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Thou Profligate! To Hug, To Clasp, To Imbrace, And throw your robust Arms about me like a Vulgar and Indelicate! Oh! I faint with Apprehensions of so gross Address.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh! My offended Fair!

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Inhumane! Ravisher! Oh! He takes her in his Arms and carries her off, she strugling and embracing him.

sp.speaker: Clarinda alone.
sp.p: Well this is one of the most extraordinary Scenes of Loves I ever saw, I cou'd never think a Womans Fantask wou'd ever run so high as to oppose her Inclination, and believe her Ladyship wou'd be glad to compound for a little of the Vulgar.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Confounded Jade, to stay all this while— I shall be too late— I warrant the Parson has been there this hour, and 'twas never know that they stayd for the Bride— Pin up this Favorite better— Well these Soldiers are dear Creatures and I love 'em all!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: They'll think your Ladyship was taken by Storm, to dispatch it so suddainly—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: They'll rather commend my Conduct, for yielding before I had distress'd the Garrison— (set this Ribban right)— let foolish Maids squander their time that don't know the use of it, I'll snatch the precious Minutes as they pass, and ne're stand shilly shally.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Methinks my Lady Empty takes it very patiently.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She dares not do otherwise, for fear I shou'd make Discoveries to Sir Solomon— and truly I think it Just Reprizal, as I us'd to promote her pleasure, to make her accessary to mine.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: 'Twas foolishly done in my Opinion, to trust a Gallant so near your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She grew very presuming forsooth, because one or two of her Fellows had the little Sense to prefer her to me— but the Captain knows how to distinguish Women.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: He's a fine proper Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So he is indeed— nay, we shall be a mighty pretty Couple; but he admires my Wit, it seems, more than my Beauty— Who'd ha' thought a Soldier had such Judgment— (this clumsy Carrian runs the Pins into me.)

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, it bent under my Finger.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Bent under your Finger?— make hast— now some People live all their Lives without making any Conquests, yet they Dress and are
Pretty Women too, but I can't tell how 'tis, they don't please— there's Mrs. Prim, Mrs. Giggit and Mrs. Saint Looks.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: They want the Freedom of your Ladyships Air.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nay every Body does me the Justice, to say that I have very much of Quality in my Manner— (this new Tower does not please me)

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: He's violently in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I am no less with him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Before Marriage

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Oh! 'Tis not the Fashion after, except among your ordinary People, as my Cousen my Lady Dainty says— no People of Quality go beyond just being Civil to each other, as My Lady, Your Ladyship, Or so— Well, now am I Dress'd and going to Execution, but I have resign'd my self wholly up to him to do as he pleases, or since it is a sort of War, as he Dares— (going). Add's my Life I forgot my Bridal Garters— O, No they're on, what striving there'll be about 'em and pinching ones Leggs? Well this will be a happy Night, a Young Hero and me; that's Courage and Conduct together— well I always observe that those Women are seldom happy that Wed very Young.
sp.l: But in the World they never can Miscarry,
Who at the Years of full Discretion Marry.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Solomon Empty with his Sword drawn.

sp.p: DIshonour'd, Ruin'd, Cuckol'd, and by my own Contrivance? I'll ne're out-live it— (putting the Sword to his Breast) my Mind misgives me plaguily I shall never have the Heart to do it— oh, commit Murder! I shall never enjoy my self after— I can't do it— well, tho I am abus'd, yet a living Cuckold is better than a Dead one— I see if I had been a rash Man, one of the King's Subjects might have been lost without any regard to his Person— but stay, supposing I shou'd ask my self a few Questions; how am I sure I am a Cuckold?— [changing his Voice.] Oh! Sir, I saw it under her Hand— but Sir Solomon in an Age so full of Plots, how do you know but this may be one to create Diversion?— Pardon me Sir, I see no Colour to take it that way— but tis the part of a wise Man to know the bottom before he Determines, and how if Sir Solomon Empty shou'd fix himself somewhere to over hear their Meetings and receive Conviction before he concludes her False—. There you have reason Sir, and Sir Solomon Empty shall do so, but I have no hope, uot the least Glymps of Comfort, Oh Woman, Woman, Devil, Devil!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I confess Clarinda, my proceeding does not look very generous, but if you consult your Heart, you'll find when Love has enter'd it, 'tis very little in the Power of Reason.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You need no more Apologies methinks, I shou'd ha' done so my self.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You fir'd me with commending him and Love's a catching Disease,

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Well it has gone no farther than this Letter?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You are Jealous?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: No I wou'd only find the Temper of the Man.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You need not fear it; there's but one way; Generosity will oblige a Man of Sense, and nothing move a Fool; besides Marriage is a double security, for it not only is apt to make a Man forget his Galantries abroad but renders him less acceptable there.— Few Women chuse a Married Man for a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why not, as well as the Men like a Married Woman?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p:
The Cases are very different— for a designing Woman, tho' she has Affairs with twenty Men, desires to keep 'em all to her self but a
Man that knows ever so many Women does not care if he never see any of 'em again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You talk madly; but from that it appears that the Men are the more reasonable, for if those Women had their Desires, in a little time three Parts of the Sex wou'd be forc'd to die Maids.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: To prevent that Calamity Nature, you see, has made the Men very Fickle.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Madam, Sir Solomon is gone into the Garden Room, I saw him look behind the Tapestry, and believe he designs to fix himself there.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Go, watch when he's hid, and tell me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Pray let me have my Lesson right— you say I must take this all upon my self.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But harkee! How shall I come off with Freeman? He'll make me stand to my Word?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You'll be pleas'd with that Force.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I must confess I'm very well inclin'd to him, but I wou'd not go so fast— well I have but one Scruple.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I'm affraid I shall be jealous.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I'll soon cure you, and if I get safe over this, will never make another venture.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A very Pious Determination!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You laugh—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: For no other reason but because it is my turn.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Not Clarinda that I would have you think that I am just now frighted into this resolution, or that I have taken it up on the suddain but from a long digested Thought of such a Life— for however pleasing it may appear there is something so Disturb'd, so Hazardous, so full of Fears and Disappointments; That the faint Pleasures that arise don't half atone for the Anxieties that attend 'em, so that from the sole Motive of good Sense—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: We must be Sober— now let me indeed Embrace you: Astrea, I am glad to find a Woman of Wit own it, that reason brings her to the Interests of Vertue.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Madam, the Gentleman is at the Garden-door.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Bid him stay, till he has notice to come in— Exit Fid. now for this one piece of Hypocrisie Clarinda, and then adieu to't.

Thus far 'tis well— No Body has seen me come in, and here let me
fix my self— (goes near the Scenes) now shall I see with my own Eyes the dishonour of my Family, the Bane of my Quiet! and— but it turns my Head, and I'm resolv'd to be reveng'd— ' zbud, I'll have him cut to pieces for a Dog and her Skin pull'd over her Ears and hung up in Guild-Hall, as a warning Piece to the rest of the Baggages— But hark, I hear 'em coming— my Heart Sinks, and if it be true I shall run Mad— Ay, now: Enter Astrea and Fidelia.
I'll watch every Motion—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Are you sure you left the Letter?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Very well, this is plain— S'death I've a Mind to go just now and cut her Throat—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: But 'tis hardly six a Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: you're very punctual you Whore—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I'm upon Thorns to see her, for I long to know how far this Business is gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ha! What Business? Well I shall find out the whole knot—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: You say he was with her here, last Night?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and seem'd mighty loving.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: I don't know what to make of this— but I must have Patience—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I am extreamly concern'd at her doing so, for it might ha' drawn a reflection upon me— what wou'd Sir Solomon ha' thought of my conduct if he had found a Man in the House?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ha:—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O Madam, she knew Sir Solomon was too well acquainted with your strict Vertue and unblemisht Life, to believe any thing to the Prejudice of your Honour.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Indeed I am pretty well assur'd of my Husband's Love, and 'tis my care next Heaven to deserve it; but the World Fidelia is so full of strange Hypocrisies that such an Accident as this might make him very uneasie.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: I'm in Heaven: My Wife's Honest and I am no Monster,— there must be some mistake in this Letter—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: If my Cousen takes these Libertys I must desire her to forbear her visits; for it shou'd be very modest Woman's care to preserve the reputation as well as the Conscience of Innocence, and I wou'd not for all the World have my Fidelity to my Dear Sir Solomon brought in Question.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Poor Fool: If she had heard of my unmerciful resolution to kill my self, twou'd ha' broke her heart.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I am ready to sink with Apprehensions of it—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Dear Madam, don't afflict your self so much, you lay it so near your Heart, 'twill kill you—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Hold me—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: What shall I do? But I must not stir yet—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p:
Oh: My good Lady take Comfort— smell to this Bottle— Oh, Unfortunate Accident, Bear forward dear Madam,— How unhappy
wou'd it be now if the most Vertuous Lady in the World, The Glory of all good Women, And Pattern of Chastity, shou'd dye here between my Arms: Evil befall Madam, Clarenda for this— to disturb my Lady that is so tender of her Fame and so averse to all such Wicked Practices—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay: So my Dearee is—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh, Look up Madam:— Will your Ladiship give me leave to Pinch your Nose to bring you to Life?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Now cou'd I kick that civil Jade, she can't bring her to Life without asking her leave.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Ho! Ho!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Be Comforted good Madam.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: What cou'd we say if Sir Solomon shou'd hear of it? What Excuse cou'd we make?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I can't imagin Madam, for as for my self I cou'd not tell a Lie; No not in very jest.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: And as for me Fidelia, I cou'd not forge or report an Untruth, tho' my Life lay on it, and if we can't tell how to hide it, we had better tell him the naked Truth than be catch'd in a Story.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Poor Fool!—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Be satisfy'd Madam, Sir Solomon may never know it, or if he shou'd, Heaven I hope will favour the Innocent and direct his Heart to suspect them only that are Guilty.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: That may be pray'd for, but not hop'd, for Sir Solomon is a Man of that nice Discerning and pierces presently into the most difficult Matters, and what interpretation can he make from this; a Man in the House and at so unseasonable a time? It distracts me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O dear Madam; this is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Have I surpriz'd you before the time, my Life! My Heaven!

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Villain! Dog! Oh that I durst now run him through the Back—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Speak him fair Madam, for we are but weak Women and and don't know what he may do to us— he looks like a Cut-throat.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: An Age has slipt between me and your Lips.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay, Rogue— but how will it end?—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I am ready to die—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How cou'd you be so surpriz'd my Dear, when you were to expect me at this hour?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Pray Sir keep off, my Lady never saw you or heard of you in her Life.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Abigail don't you be so quick, your Lady won't tell me so.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Good Sir, go out of my house, you are mistaken and I don't know you, hoe!—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How not know me Madam, when I was here with you but last Night?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p:
Ha! 〈…〉
done very ill, yet I shall own my self obliged to you, if you pursue your Mistake no farther and leave us.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Nay then I must.— (Puts his Hand in his Pocket.)

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O good Madam take care of your self, he's going to pull out a Pistol— (kneeling) good Sir don't kill us take all we have and spare our Lives.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay Lord, what shall I do? I stand just against him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Mrs. Airsmock, I'le spare your Lives— but not your Shame, Madam— there's my Invitation, farewel Jilt—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: What's this I see, my Note to my Cousen? how, Fidelia, have you betray'd me?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I know nothing of it, indeed Madam; I left it at her House, as I hope to be Married.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay, Mrs. Matchiavel, is this your Contrivance? but thus I'le reward you for it. Draws.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: O! Sir Solomon, don't kill her, let us first know the bottom— but how came you here?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: I saw something towards, and step'd behind the Hangings, and now Astrea I am satisfi'd of your Honour, and nothing shall make me question it— but this Quean I'll have hang'd; corrupt the Wife of my Bosom, and make her false to my Bed!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, What's the Matter good People?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O pray Madam, satisfie Sir. Solomon who will kill me else, did not you receive a Note of my Ladies that I left at your House?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha, ha, is that all?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: That all? ay Madam, and if you are concern'd in it, pray let me know the meaning of it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Solomon, I am sorry I was not a witness of the Mirth.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Mirth, Cousen? you wou'd ha' been disappointed— but pray bring us out of this Confusion, here has been a Man here that wou'd ha' been very free with me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha, ha, why that's it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: That's it, Madam!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: And to justifie his coming threw me the Note I had sent to you— I thought I shou'd ha' dy'd, and your Mirth as you call it, might ha' cost me my Life; my Maid murder'd, and Sir Solomon remain'd assur'd of my Dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I'm sorry it had so different Effects— I find I am to ask pardon for what I thought you wou'd thank me— but to set all right again, this Gentleman is one that I shall Marry to Morrow, and I thought the occasion of a Wedding, and the season of a Christmass, might justifie an innocent Frolick; and observing the Note you sent me this Morning without
out a Superscription to be so worded, that it might come from me as well as you, and that there was not so much difference between our Persons and Dress, but might deceive him a Minute or two, and not fail, I thought of making a very ridiculous mistake.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! a very good Plot I' faith, and I'm sorry it did not take; only my Dearee is such a fearful Fool, or it wou'd ha' made good sport— you must know Cousen, I accidentally coming in, had slipt behind the Tapestry and heard all.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then you had all the pleasure of it to your Self— I design'd to be there too, but was interrupted by an impertinent Visiter, my Lady Chatt— but how came your Sword drawn Sir Solomon, you han't kill'd my Lover?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: No, no, no, he went away before— but you must know, as the thing appear'd then, I was so foolish as to believe that it was a contrivance of Fidelia's and in the present Passion Cousen, did'nt know what I did—

sp.speaker: F.d.
sp.p: I'm glad the Truth's come to Light—

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: But all's well now Cousen, all's well, and I applaud you for your Plot, I always took you for a sly Baggage— but come come, we'll send for the Fidles, and you for your Lover, for for ought I know, you have lost him— he was plaguily snubb'd poor Fellow; come along, we'll have the Business done now— you shan't lose a Night Coz, besides to keep you in Countenance, my Lady Dainty is doing the same thing, and we'll be merry together—

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Rarely come off, the success of this wou'd almost tempt me to break my Vow.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Dainty and Cleremont. (Hand in Hand) Follow'd by the Dr. and Attendants with Musick, Dancers, &c.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Well, there is nothing shows so visibly the remaining Footsteps of our primitive Barbarism as the noise at Weddings; huh! huh!—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: It serves to recommend the Pleasures that succeed, and make us taste the Joys of silence with a higher relish— They sit.
Dr. You'll grieve to see your Art out-done; I bring an approv'd Remedy.

div.stage: (A Bridal Song, and after it a Mimick Dance.)
Enter Sir Solomon, Astrea, Freeman, Clarinda Sylvia and Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: My Lady Dainty, I wish you Joy, and you too, dear Cleremont, an Hour hence you may wish it these— we heard of your Ladyship's design for a Wedding-Jigg to Night, and my Cousen and this honest Captain were resolv'd to complement your Ladyship, and join in the same Dance— I warrant they shake their Heels rarely.—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Methinks the Stile of Sir Solomon is very extraordinary.—

sp.speaker: Ast. Clar.
sp.p: We wish your Ladyship Joy.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I wonder People of any Rank should use such vulgar Salutations.—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You see Sir Solomon the success of your Counsels.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Why every thing I do is lucky— I am the most overjoy'd Man o' this side the Globe— but you can't imagine what a sly Rogue the Captain has been in this Matter shall I tell him Tom?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: No, Prithee let it alone till after Supper.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay you Dog, your Thoughts run upon nothing but after Supper.— But Cleremont, you'll Dye with Laughing, such Plots, and Counterplots.— Harkee! Tom, not a word to the Women of our first Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: For if my Dearee shou'd but hear of so irreligious a purpose, it wou'd break her Heart. It seems she is one or other, the most reserv'd, most pious, of such nice Honour, and the fearfull'st Fool,— well, I am the happiest Man in the World.—

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: In a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: And next to my own Happiness, I must Congratulate my Friends.— Dear Cleremont, I'm overjoy'd at thy good Fortune— why thy Wife looks better already— is it not possible to make her speak like one of us?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: All things by Degrees, Sir Solomon, I must not over-dose her.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Nothing pleases me so much as to think that all this happen'd thro' my Contrivance— Tom, Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Thou art a great Man that's certain.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For Intriguing—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Truly Madam I wonder how this Ill-bred Custom prevails among People of Figure? This Singing, this Dancing and this Tumult, is so like the Mob Solemnities of a May-Day, Huh! Huh! Huh!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And the Bride is us'd just like their Pole, for all the Town to Dance round.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Directly so; well, certainly if it were not for the Pleasure of ruling after, no Woman of Quality wou'd suffer her self to be treated so like a Commoner.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: The grosser part of the Ceremony is to come Madam, and that is throwing the Stocking.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That indeed is a thing that insults us so near, that I wonder the Men have not thought it their Interest to lay it down.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I suppose it is to take away the rem ins of Modesty in a Married Woman all at once, for they think that Quality is properly the Vertue of a Maid—

div.stage: Enter Footman that Whispers Sir Solomon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Tom, take hold of your Mistress, the Parson's in the next Room— let's dispatch that and then for the Supper and then— for the Posset you Rogue!

sp.speaker: Ast. Cla.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Ha!
This is his contrivance.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Cousen Sir Solomon, I'm your humble Servant, and Miss my Cousen, Clarinda this is very kindly done.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: what does this old strumpet Mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Faith I can't tell I suppose some joke of Freeman's.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: My Cousen, my Lady Dainty! This was extemely obliging, to summon all your Friends to the Celebration of our Nuptials— I don't know how I shall be able to return this Favour, but the Captain, Madam, must answer for me—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What Captain, and what Nuptials do you speak of, Mrs. Friendlove?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your Ladyship has a mind to give me some confusions, but your Ladyship need not be told that in half an Hour at most, my Name it is to be Freeman.

sp.speaker: Cle. Sir Sol.
sp.p: Freeman!
— Here's another Plot, another Plot!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How Madam, are your pretentions to my Husband?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your Husband?— why— am I deceiv'd then? Miss, Captain, pray speak, am I Cheated? Dear Captain Cousen are you a Rogue? Ha! Are you false to me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why what can be said? you stay'd so long that I was quite out of Patience, and seeing the Parson, the Musick and all things ready, and this Lady in Humour and rather than disappoint my Lady Dainty, I ingag'd my self here— that's all.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: That's all?

sp.speaker: Cle. Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You false ungrateful Fellow, to serve a Woman of my Relations so. (Aside) But this damn'd Jade to make me wait so long: She was an hour looking for my false Teeth, if I had layn in 'em as I us'd to do at my Lady Topers, all had been well— I'll turn her away immediately— but first I wish you all jealous, when you have no reason, and secure when you have, and may every Body think your Wives Handsome, but your selves; and may your Children be as dull as if they were lawfully begot.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A heavy Curse.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Farewel Hermaphrodite,— well this is a night of Intrigues, nothing but Stratagems; Tom, I begin to be in Love with my self, when I think I was the first Ingineer.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Nay 'twas all your own Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: All things break out so, luckily: But stay there's Careless left how shall we provide for him, he's a very honest Fellow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Don't Name that Sir Solomon, if you intend to prefer me— but now I have no hopes of being a General, I think I must go into the Country, and be my Elder Brother's Butler.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: Ay, thou hadst always a kindness for the Cellar, but if you wou'd make your Fortune under him, get to be his Steward, Iack, rather than his Butler, for then you may come to be richer than your Master in a little time if you have any Discretion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Which I never had— but there's another way I like better, if you wou'd promise me your Interest.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: If it be not to serve the Court-Party, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not in the least 'tis only to perswade that Lady (who I have found is your Relation) to think better of me than I do of my self, and take me for Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.p: That's a long Lease, but she has 200 l. a Year to keep it in repair— (Turning to Sylvia) well Cousen, what think you of this Handsome Scoundrel? H'as been a Volunteer a great while, let him now fight under a Commission.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You see Madam, how Ominous it was to begin with a Quarrel, I knew 'twou'd be a Match, by our Scolding before hand.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: If we don't after, 'twill be well enough.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: We must not be singular— now and then 'twill be necessary to be like the rest of the World.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Well Clarinda, I wish you perfect Joy and must own to you, that your life is the Happiest— there all is Quiet, all is Peace, there is nothing to steal the Colour from your Cheeks, or betray you to Surprizes, and now I am convinc'd of the Folly, the Confusion and the Adversity of Mine.
sp.l: The Guilty still with anxious Cares are prest,
The truly Good alone are truly Blest.

div.head: EPILOGUE, By a FRIEND.
div.l: LET none hereafter Plays Vngodly call,
For this was writ to mortifie you all.
No Parson's here expos'd, no Brothel storm'd,
But a kind handsome keeping Wife Reform'd.
A sign the Youth the World n'er understood,
Or else he would not dare to be so good.
He must the Fame he aims at quite disown,
Who draws good Characters to spoil his own.
This to excuse I thought a Friend he'd need,
And came— sick as I am, his Cause to plead:
'Tis the first Visit I protest I've made.
You're sometimes kind to what I do before you;
Pity the Youth, for my sake I implore you,
Hissing to Death my tender Organ Wounds!
And a sick Ear abhors ungrateful Sounds:
Yet can Applause though ne'er so loud give Ease,
For they who flatter Women always please.
Then vain Assistance will I now explore
In Physick and Astrology no more.
You, dear Physicians, must my Health insure,
And t'other Visit will confirm my Cure;
Else what's already done— is all in vain,
And I relapse— till you come here again.
By you I shall be always to be seen,
For whate'er ails the sickly Fair within,
The Doctor at all Seasons is let in.
